quotes.topic_title: Cold open: surprising signup experiment lift
quotes.text: We just asked for forgiveness and put these questions into the silent flow and ran as Navy test with a small group.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A pragmatic experimentation tactic: ship a small, low-visibility test quickly to learn before seeking broad buy-in.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: surprising signup experiment lift
quotes.text: And I'm fully expecting, "Okay, this is going to hurt our numbers, but maybe it won't be so bad and I'm going to be prepared to advocate the power of this data that we're getting."
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Shows how to pre-commit to learning value even when you expect a metric hit, helping teams run bolder experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: surprising signup experiment lift
quotes.text: I'm not kidding, an improved conversion.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive result that sets up the key lesson: experiments often surprise you, so test rather than assume.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: surprising signup experiment lift
quotes.text: There's no personalization, nothing past it, just the questions. An improved conversion by like 5%, just improved signups.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Concrete data point: adding signup questions (often assumed to add friction) increased conversion by ~5%.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we dig into Laura's career growth framework and the importance of carving your own path versus waiting for one to be carved for you.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical career mental model: proactively shape your trajectory rather than waiting for opportunities to appear.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also get into a bunch of tactical and surprising advice around running experiments, making decisions on gut versus data, developing your growth strategy and how to sell your product to developers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews several practitioner-relevant areas—experimentation, decision-making, growth strategy, and developer marketing/sales.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The week we recorded this chat turned out to be Laura's first week in a new gig as head of growth for Amplitude taking over for a previous legendary guest, Elena Verna.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides situational context that the discussion comes from a fresh transition into a new growth leadership role.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Prior to Amplitude, Laura was VP of product and growth at a company called Rapid. Before that, she spent over seven years at Twilio as Head of Growth and PM lead of the growth platform and experimentation platform at Twilio.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes credibility and a concrete example of deep experience building growth and experimentation platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can move your cash and the US treasuries with the flexibility of a bank account.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Public.com read)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach to making traditionally complex treasury investing as liquid and usable as a checking/savings workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can access your cash whenever you want, even before your treasury bills hit maturity.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Public.com read)
quotes.context: Counterintuitive claim that treasuries can be treated as accessible cash rather than locked-up capital, changing how practitioners think about cash management.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Public will automatically reinvest your treasury bills at maturity so you don't have to do anything to continue growing your yield.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Public.com read)
quotes.context: Actionable automation idea: remove operational overhead (manual reinvestment) to sustain compounding returns.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: A concrete experimentation methodology: segmenting results across key dimensions to uncover heterogeneous effects and avoid misleading averages.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics and instead you turn north star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions and payments.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: Encourages a metrics framework shift from shallow engagement to business- and lifecycle-aligned north-star outcomes in experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Laura joins: new role and Twilio tenure
quotes.text: We had that in Twilio and I got pretty, pretty high up there after a while. We had a stack rank and a spreadsheet.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A concrete example of an internal mechanism (stack rank + spreadsheet) for tracking employee tenure/order, which can shape culture and identity.

quotes.topic_title: Laura joins: new role and Twilio tenure
quotes.text: Yeah, no, I was very proud to crack the top 50. That was my claim the same because as people left, you move up. Right?
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A specific, memorable data point about early-employee status—and the dynamic that tenure rank changes as attrition happens.

quotes.topic_title: Laura joins: new role and Twilio tenure
quotes.text: Well, yeah, right. On one hand it's like, "Ooh, very cool." And one of the OGs on the other hand, it's like, "Oh my gosh, this person's [inaudible 00:05:47]. Bummer."
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that “moving up” in tenure rank is bittersweet because it often reflects teammates leaving.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth: limits of the traditional path
quotes.text: But the problem with it is that you're limited to what your manager's ability is to advocate for you, to promote you.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Highlights a key constraint of the traditional “work hard + manager advocacy” career-growth approach.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth: limits of the traditional path
quotes.text: And something that I learned really early on in my career, I was very lucky to learn by accident, was at a company called Bandwidth, which is my first real job.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Sets up a concrete early-career example of creating leverage by spotting patterns and proposing a scalable solution.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth: limits of the traditional path
quotes.text: And the main learning that I had from that was, which really took life at Twilio and absolutely worked for me there and I'm happy to talk about that too. But the core that learning was, your executive team and executive teams at companies are often very sharp, but the nature of their day-to-day just does not link them with customers.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Introduces the core mental model: executives are smart but structurally disconnected from customer reality, creating an opportunity for ICs.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth: limits of the traditional path
quotes.text: And so that means that your superpower is in really pulling those insights in and bringing them to life, staying close to the customer.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to create career leverage: become the conduit for customer insights to leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Career growth: limits of the traditional path
quotes.text: There's not a single leader or executive that isn't going to be stoked to hear about valuable customer insights that highlight problems they might not be seeing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A practical persuasion tip: customer-backed insights are a reliable way to get leadership attention and drive change.

quotes.topic_title: Build internal brand through customer understanding
quotes.text: And I think it's important to just recognize they're not going to follow all your ideas, but they're always looking for better ideas.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical mindset shift for influencing without expecting immediate adoption of your proposals.

quotes.topic_title: Build internal brand through customer understanding
quotes.text: And it's almost like building up your individual brand a little bit. And I think one of the most powerful and accessible ways is learning about your customers.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Frames customer understanding as a repeatable method for building internal reputation and leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Build internal brand through customer understanding
quotes.text: There's always those people at companies who's like, "Oh, well, she just knows our customers or he just knows our customers, they just know our customers. They just know."
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Highlights the recognizable “customer expert” archetype that earns trust and visibility across the org.

quotes.topic_title: Build internal brand through customer understanding
quotes.text: And that's not always an immediate payoff, but it often does give you a trajectory outside of just your role and just your manager. It gives you something a little bit broader.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Counterbalances short-term ROI thinking by emphasizing long-term career compounding from shared customer learnings.

quotes.topic_title: Build internal brand through customer understanding
quotes.text: So maybe a simple way of describing to mirror back what you're saying is carve your own path.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable career advice to proactively shape opportunities rather than waiting for managerial direction.

quotes.topic_title: Twilio example: voice-of-customer to create growth team
quotes.text: I made it my own personal policy to like, hey, I'm going to do my job. And I'm going to do well, I'm going to keep notes of things I'm doing well and all that stuff because it's good, but I'm also going to get to know our customers. And I'm going to get to know our customers really well and I'm going to pay attention when I'm connecting with them, not just about the space I'm in, but just broadly what are some of the pain points and things they're articulating that are relevant to the business and what we're trying to get done.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A repeatable personal operating system: excel at your role while systematically collecting customer pain points beyond your immediate scope.

quotes.topic_title: Twilio example: voice-of-customer to create growth team
quotes.text: And one of the things that came up was that users were struggling and folks were struggling to get started and use Twilio. And that contrasted so deeply to some of the things that our executive team was saying and had high conviction in our company had high conviction, which is that Twilio was so easy to use.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Highlights a common blind spot: internal brand conviction can diverge sharply from real customer experience, creating an opportunity to drive change with evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Twilio example: voice-of-customer to create growth team
quotes.text: But there was another tactic that I could take, and I just started sharing a voice of the customer report. I started sharing my insights, started writing down and just sharing them. And it became with digest and eventually people were like, "Hey, can you share it with me? Can you share with me? Can you get on your list? Can share with me?"
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for influence without authority: publish a lightweight VoC digest until demand pulls it into the org.

quotes.topic_title: Twilio example: voice-of-customer to create growth team
quotes.text: So then this established me as that person who knows about the customer even after short tenure.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Shows how consistently packaging customer insights can quickly create a durable reputation and platform for bigger initiatives.

quotes.topic_title: Twilio example: voice-of-customer to create growth team
quotes.text: I put stuff together for it, but it was the meeting before the meeting had already been done by this other thing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: the real decision happens before the formal pitch—build trust and allies in advance.

quotes.topic_title: More career tactics: ungate knowledge and be an SME
quotes.text: Your insights are extremely valuable. You're talking to customers every day more about their problems and their pain than a lot of other people do.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A reminder that customer-facing roles have uniquely high-leverage knowledge that can create cross-team influence and opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: More career tactics: ungate knowledge and be an SME
quotes.text: Go to your general Slack channel or whatever and just be like, "Hey, just wrote some tips for how to do it, some ways that I am good at this."
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for proactively sharing expertise to build visibility and become a go-to SME.

quotes.topic_title: More career tactics: ungate knowledge and be an SME
quotes.text: I've done this stuff and then it's helped my manager promote me.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive framing that proactive self-advocacy can actually make it easier for managers to support promotions.

quotes.topic_title: More career tactics: ungate knowledge and be an SME
quotes.text: it makes it a lot easier when those people have had some access or exposure or whatever to you in a positive light.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A practical mental model for promotions: create positive cross-org exposure so calibration rooms already “know” your impact.

quotes.topic_title: More career tactics: ungate knowledge and be an SME
quotes.text: Yeah, ungate your knowledge I think is the buzzword that I'm hearing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A memorable principle for career acceleration: proactively share what you know instead of hoarding it within your role.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation story: signup questions increased conversion
quotes.text: I'm not kidding, an improved conversion. There's no personalization, nothing past it, just the questions. It improved conversion by 5%, just improved signups.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A concrete, counterintuitive experiment result showing that adding friction to signup can increase conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation story: signup questions increased conversion
quotes.text: When you think about it, when users are signing up for your product for the very first time, it's new. This is new, that means it's scary.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mental model: optimize onboarding by accounting for first-time user anxiety, not just speed.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation story: signup questions increased conversion
quotes.text: And so by putting in these questions it's like, what's your language? It's like, "Oh, I do. I code a JavaScript and I can select that." Well, that's something I'm uncomfortable with. That would make my journey easier. Like "Yeah, bingo. That's my use case. Okay, I'm in the right place here."
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism: “good friction” can reassure users by confirming fit and reducing uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation story: signup questions increased conversion
quotes.text: And the simple catchy thing I say is that ultimately the learning here is, bad friction is bad, and good friction is good. There's no such thing as it being simple. It's just all friction is bad, which is what I had assumed going into this.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A memorable framework that challenges the default growth assumption that all friction should be removed.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding psychology: hide scary steps like telecom
quotes.text: Developers when they were coming into Twilio, it was things that were familiar to them. APIs, the language they're coding in, code samples, documentation, things like the bogeyman, the things that would psychologically trip them up, telecom, phone numbers.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Highlights a practical onboarding heuristic: lead with familiar developer-native concepts and treat unfamiliar domain steps as psychological blockers to manage.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding psychology: hide scary steps like telecom
quotes.text: However, in a self-serve experience, when you don't have that safe person sitting next to you being like, "Don't worry, it's going to be okay, I'm going to take you through this crazy telecom journey." They're on their own, but that's psyche telling is them like, "Oh my god, telecom. Well, I can't do that. That sounds scary. We're getting a phone number configured. Whoa, I'm out of my debt."
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Explains why “logical” step ordering can fail in self-serve onboarding: without human reassurance, anxiety can dominate behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding psychology: hide scary steps like telecom
quotes.text: It was like, "Oh, get a phone number, let's go configure it." Not as step one, not as the leading thing, but embedded. And the analogy I have for this is pilling a hot dog.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for sequencing onboarding: hide the scary prerequisite inside an appealing, confidence-building flow.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding psychology: hide scary steps like telecom
quotes.text: And guess what? Even though we're a good amount of the console and they're going off and we had no easy return button, it converted better because we were addressing the big problem that was there at the time, which is their psyche.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A concrete example that optimizing for user psychology can beat conventional UX best practices (like keeping users in-product with easy return paths).

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding psychology: hide scary steps like telecom
quotes.text: But so again, the psyche of your user is such a critical thing to be thinking about. And if something very logical isn't converting well sometimes, it means that you're battling against the psyche of a user and you want to take a step back and think about and learn about where someone is psychologically in your space.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic advice: when funnels don’t convert, investigate psychological readiness—not just flow logic or UI.

quotes.topic_title: Iterate vs redesign: why big rewrites often fail
quotes.text: Companies like Netflix and Microsoft, there's over and over again 80 plus percent. Some companies say 90% of things fail. And so the closer you get to something that you go bear your head in the sand or go into an attic and build something for six months and ship it, the more likely it is that you are going to ship the 80% wrong stuff.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Grounds the case for iteration in real-world failure rates and warns against long, isolated rebuild cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Iterate vs redesign: why big rewrites often fail
quotes.text: failure doesn't have to be a wall, it can be a compass, it can be the thing that leads you to the right thing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for using failed experiments as directional learning rather than a dead end.

quotes.topic_title: Iterate vs redesign: why big rewrites often fail
quotes.text: I tell my teams all the time, if it's not embarrassing, you've gone too far. Got to be embarrassing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Actionable bar for how small/rough early tests should be to maximize speed of learning and minimize risk.

quotes.topic_title: Iterate vs redesign: why big rewrites often fail
quotes.text: You have to understand the problem perfectly. You have to then understand who's having the problem perfectly, the customer. At what time they're having the problem.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: A checklist-style framework explaining why success rates are low: multiple alignment points must all be correct.

quotes.topic_title: Iterate vs redesign: why big rewrites often fail
quotes.text: So in that context, it's almost like incredible. We do succeed 20 to 10% of the time given everything that has to line up.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing that normalizes low win rates and encourages designing a strategy around frequent failure.

quotes.topic_title: Fail faster: cheaper validation than A/B tests
quotes.text: And AB testing is one of the most expensive kinds of ways to validate an experiment.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Reframes A/B testing as a costly validation method, motivating teams to seek cheaper pre-validation steps first.

quotes.topic_title: Fail faster: cheaper validation than A/B tests
quotes.text: And so I think the key is to just think through, "Okay, what are the things I can do to quickly validate what these ideas are that we [inaudible 00:39:59]?"
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Provides a practical guiding question for designing faster validation loops before committing heavy resources.

quotes.topic_title: Fail faster: cheaper validation than A/B tests
quotes.text: And you can do that with painted doors, which is where you test rate the concept and the idea before it exists versus the actual experience.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete pre-validation methodology (painted-door tests) to assess demand without building the feature.

quotes.topic_title: Fail faster: cheaper validation than A/B tests
quotes.text: The only things you want to get to that deep AB testing environment or ones that have been vetted along the way.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Establishes a stage-gate approach: reserve expensive A/B tests for ideas that survive earlier validation filters.

quotes.topic_title: Fail faster: cheaper validation than A/B tests
quotes.text: So I think I more advocate for that side. Let's fail fast by using those tools rather than figuring out a way that you can rise above where everyone else is operating and figure out ways to solve all that complex stuff better because that's going to be challenging, but you can always get better at experimenting and validating things faster.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Encourages a counterintuitive focus on speeding up validation (fail faster) instead of trying to dramatically improve raw experiment hit rates.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But how do you take it from a shiny toy to an actual business tool that helps you do your actual job?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames a practical litmus test for evaluating generative AI: usefulness in real workflows vs. novelty.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Writer is an enterprise grade generative AI platform built specifically for the needs of businesses and already widely deployed at world-class brands like Uber, Spotify, HubSpot, and UiPath.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete social proof examples of enterprise adoption that practitioners can use when assessing vendor maturity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With writer, you can break through content bottlenecks across your organization from marketing webpages to sales e-mails in product messages to creating high quality on-brand content at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable use-case framework: target cross-functional content bottlenecks and standardize on-brand output.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And unlike other AI applications, writers' training happens securely on your data and your style and brand guidelines that you provide specific to your organization.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out an enterprise-ready methodology: train on internal data plus explicit brand guidelines to improve fit and governance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The result is that you get consistent content in your brand voice at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Summarizes the operational goal for AI content systems: consistency and scalability in a defined brand voice.

quotes.topic_title: Data vs gut: confidence thresholds in experiments
quotes.text: But those of us converting users and trying to upsell folks, we are very fortunate to not have that level of burden on us and we can take advantage of that. And so there are definitely times where I will advocate for and I will push for and I will myself use lower confidence intervals and 95%, especially if that doubles amount of experiments that you can run in a year.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Contrarian take: in many product contexts, relaxing strict statistical thresholds can increase learning velocity and total impact.

quotes.topic_title: Data vs gut: confidence thresholds in experiments
quotes.text: End of the day, these are all methods that we use to try to validate the hypotheses that we have. And if you're doing a 95% confidence in a role, you're still accepting a 5%, some amount of false success, do that a little bit more, challenge you to do that a little bit more. And then run way more experience. If you look at the net of what your team is doing over the course of year, what you're doing over the course of a year, you will be positive.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Reframes experimentation as portfolio math over time rather than perfection per test, encouraging more shots on goal with managed risk.

quotes.topic_title: Data vs gut: confidence thresholds in experiments
quotes.text: You must have this game plan set before you run something.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Actionable rule: pre-commit decision criteria and validation plans to avoid post-hoc rationalization.

quotes.topic_title: Data vs gut: confidence thresholds in experiments
quotes.text: Failure mode that I see so many teams fall into is they'll run the experiment or whatever it is and then they'll make the data fit the hypothesis.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Highlights a common experimentation anti-pattern (p-hacking / motivated reasoning) that teams should actively guard against.

quotes.topic_title: Data vs gut: confidence thresholds in experiments
quotes.text: And always, always, always, if you're going to accept more risk of a false success or false positive, false negative, you want to then be really thinking about how you're going to harden your validation of a hypothesis.
quotes.speaker: Laura Schaffer
quotes.context: Provides a risk-compensation methodology: if you lower confidence thresholds, strengthen validation via additional evidence streams.
